title: An Indoor Rainforest
content:
Weaving together an experience of nature and marketplace, Changi Jewel Airport boasts one of the world’s largest indoor gardens, the Forest Valley.

Built on sustainable engineering principles, over 60,000 specially adapted plants help regulate temperature and absorb carbon.

With rotating plant displays, the valley constantly evolves, orienting the passenger experience to be engaging, restorative and soothing, bringing in locals and tourists alike under a communal roof and dramatically echoing Singapore’s reputation as a ‘Garden City’.
funFact: Greenery covers an area of 21,000–22,000 m² across Jewel Changi Airport, amounting to ~16% of the terminal’s total area.

title: Singapore's Crown Jewel
content:
In 2013, Singapore saw the need for increased airport capacity as an opportunity to create a global icon: Jewel Changi Airport.

This massive undertaking, requiring billions in resources, successfully blended operational functionality with world-class design.

The result is Singapore’s ‘Crown Jewel’—a complex structure featuring a free-form toroidal glass roof, rainwater harvesting systems, and a climate-controlled indoor forest unlike any other.
funFact: The entire Forest Valley acts as a natural sound-softener; vegetation naturally absorbs and diffuses noise, reducing echo inside the immense glass dome and giving an unexpectedly calm ambience.

title: Our Story
content:
From a small fishing village before 1819, Singapore transformed into a thriving metropolis within 7 decades through maximising land use and developing its people as its greatest resource – brutal efficiency was key to her survival.

Today, over 90% of the island’s land is developed for public and economic use while boasting one of the busiest ports globally, and ranking among the world’s top 3 financial hubs – annual trade flows exceed S$1 trillion despite limited natural resources.
funFact: Nearly 25% of Singapore’s current land area did not exist in 1960 and was created through land reclamation.

title: Journey Through the Skies
content:
Singapore’s civil aviation story began in 1937 with a modest central airport.

As air travel demand grew, the need for larger, modern facilities led to the opening of Changi Airport’s Terminal 1 in 1981, with continual expansion since.

Today, Changi is consistently ranked the world’s best airport, handling over 1,000 daily aircraft movements.

Planning ahead for 50 years of development, Singapore intends to install its fifth terminal that will match the current airport’s entire passenger and aircraft capacity.
funFact: Changi Airport was built on reclaimed land over former swamps and the Changi coastline, using sand imported from neighbouring countries.
